We would all agree with you, Dr. Krugman ; that neither the President nor his people will convince anyone that they are particularly bright.  Still, I believe they do mean well.  They are the sort of well-credentialed liberal do-gooders without the capacity for critical thinking, but with with an overload of sentiment and emotion to compensate.  As a nation we simply have to wait them out until we can replace them en-masse in 2012.

If Obama were truly a liberal, he wouldn't believe that trickle-down economics -- from tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires, and business tax breaks for companies sitting on record wads of cash -- will dribble down to the rest of us.

But Obama is only a liberal in jargon; his actions speaks volumes to the contrary.

Any way you look at it, the Obama tax deal is bad for average Americans.

As you pointed out last week -- what little stimulative effect the tax deal may have will end at the beginning of 2012, giving Republicans plenty of time to blame the Obama Administration for not fixing the economy. I'm not sure that matters, because there is very little daylight between Republicans & Obama anyway. As James Galbraith said in a speech at Harvard last month, Obama listens to the guys who caused many of our economic problems. He surrounded "himself with holdover appointments from the Bush and even the Clinton administrations: ... Geithner..., Bernanke, and ... Summers. These men have no commitment to the base, no commitment to the Democratic Party as a whole, no particular commitment to Barack Obama, and none to the broad objective of national economic recovery...." Galbraith sees Obama as Bush without the resolve; that is, Worse than Bush.

Obama has never stopped carrying water for Wall Street & big business. This week he's holding some business roundtable with 20 CEOs. It wouldn't surprise me if Obama is planning to take Newt Gingrich's hilarious advice to just ask these businessmen how & when they would like the federal government to raise their taxes.

In short, Obama & Geithner made the deal with McConnell & Boehner because they all largely agreed anyway. It was a deal hammered out among Republicans. It's a one-hundred percent Republican deal.

The country would be better off if Congressional Democrats refused to take the deal. Here's why. The argument that raising taxes on the middle class would be catastrophic is a fallacy. If taxes go up for working Americans, wages will go up, too. That is what has happened historically. On the other hand, if taxes go down -- with these tax cuts -- guess what? Wages will go down, too. That also is what has happened historically. Average workers wages were highest -- what Alan Greenspan called "wage inflation" -- when taxes were highest.

Particularly because estimates are that under the Obama tax deal, taxes for the poorest Americans will actually RISE, let's let everyone's taxes go up. Within a short time, their wages will go up, too. [See Thom Hartmann on this.]

As for the other "good deals" Obama extracted: (1) The payroll deduction in the Obama plan is just a scam to make Social Security insolvent so benefits can be cut. (2) The unemployment benefits ARE vitally important, but I really believe enough Republicans will blink when their constituents demand the benefits be continued.

So, Congress, just say no to the Republican deal. It's worse than no deal.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

One of the Obama administration's biggest mistake is referring to what's going on in the economy as a 'recovery.' Everybody here in Main Street knows that things suck and are going to suck for at least a few more years. Bernie Sanders is right and Alan Grayson is right. The government should not go along with extending the Bush tax cuts and use the money to hire about 3 million people at $30,000 a year. Retro-fitting homes and schools, building windmills or nuclear power plants, or picking up litter in the National Parks. Anything.

Mr. Krugman the only thing all involved care about is kicking the can down the road for some other poor chump to have it explode in their face.

In the mean time all involved will puff out their chests, strike poses, make profound pronouncements and pretend to conduct government. No one cares about anything beyond the moment.

We are the ones that allowed this to happen. We are worthy of our fate.
The biggest question I need answered, Dr. Krugman, is when will the President fire Timothy Geithner and hire you in his stead?  Now THAT would be a step in the right direction!

I agree that, in comparison to the ideal, the compromise is not a good deal. And I agree that we should not be selling it as anything near the type of stimulus that is needed to get our economy moving again. However, there other considerations here.

First, this is about more than economic stimulus. It is also about making sure that 2 million people do not lose their unemployment benefits over the holidays and that 7 million Americans have additional benefits over the coming 13 months. This is critically important for the millions who would otherwise be reaching the end of their safety net. That is why I like to call it the unemployment benefits/tax cuts compromise, rather than just the tax cuts compromise.

Second, what is the realistic option to this compromise? Republicans have proven over the past two years that they put their own partisan gain ahead of economic recovery, that they will hold the unemployed hostage in the name of making the rich richer, that they do not believe in economic stimulus, and that things will be even worse when they take over the House next year. In light of this, none of the good things in this compromise could be obtained otherwise, and the tax cuts for wealthy, including the estate tax changes, would probably turn out even worse if left to next year.

Finally, let's keep our eye on who the real culprits are here. We may have legitimate reasons to be disappointed in President Obama, but it is the Republicans who are the real bad actors here. If we progressives want to make political progress, let's focus our vitriol against the Republican hostage takers, not against a President who is doing what he thinks need to be done to get an extension of unemployment benefits and some stimulus for our economy.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

And you don't even mention the next big fail of the McConnell-Boehner Congress, reduced government spending to match the other segments of the economy. Will the continued good fortune of the Wall St Casino be able to keep the rest of us from a second dip into depression?

If Obama thinks he is sacrificing his presidency to hurt the weakest the least, he is making a bad bargain because it proves his own weakness.

You could give us a checklist of outcomes so that we can tally numbers to the direction of "progress". That way, even your worst detractors (not that you care) have proof of their pudding.

This is not just daylight robbery, it is daylight main-street rape (sorry - bad word). Do people see ?

And then there was no Soviet Union...

I think that it is very important to have wars. Lots of wars! Then we can keep feeding Haliburton and Rapiscan and all those other fine, fine Republican-driven corporations lots of money.

Naturally, it's very important that everyone has a credit card. Calibrated, so that folks will charge to the very limits of their ability, even if that's not much. As long as the interest rates are high, that's all that matters. The big banks need that money, don't you know?

We do need to have manufactured enemies. Blame the poor! If much of the country's ills can be set on the doorstep of them Illegals from Mexico, then we don't have to look in the mirror and ask ourselves how we got so ignorant and apathetic.

And so forth.

I, myself, am heart-broken over the thought that the richest get to keep their tax cuts. I was so hopeful and now I feel so cynical and bitter.

As much as I still adore Joe Biden, he's starting to kill me too.

What is this country coming to?

Cali S.
